docs.lead_paragraph: Reagan Administration officials said today that they would try again to require 6,400 hospitals around the country to provide food and medical care to severely handicapped infants, even though a Federal district judge struck down a similar requirement last April. Officials from the Department of Health and Human Services disclosed their plans to pediatricians, obstetricians, gynecologists and hospital administrators at a meeting this afternoon. The new proposal is to be accompanied by a fuller explanation of the reasons for issuing the rule, which many doctors and hospitals oppose as a Federal intrusion into the practice of medicine. The text of the rule itself is almost identical to the one struck down by Judge Gerhard A. Gesell. The Administration is appealing his ruling.

headline.main: ADMINISTRATION TRIES AGAIN ON CARE LAW FOR IMPAIRED INFANTS

docs.snippet: Reagan Administration officials said today that they would try again to require 6,400 hospitals around the country to provide food and medical care to severely handicapped infants, even though a Federal district judge struck down a similar...

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times
